qa_list.question: What is the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree?
qa_list.answer: The Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree is a professional Master of Science degree offered by the Language Technologies Institute (LTI), a department in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University. The MCDS degree offers students with a Bachelor's degree the opportunity to improve their training with advanced study in Computer Science and Machine Learning.

qa_list.question: Who is the target audience for the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) program?
qa_list.answer: The MCDS Program caters to students with basic analytic skills and a strong aptitude for mathematics, programming, and logical reasoning. An undergraduate degree in Computer Science is not required.

qa_list.question: How long does it typically take to complete the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) program?
qa_list.answer: The MCDS Program is typically a 16-month program consisting of courses, seminars, and a final project.

qa_list.question: What are the core curriculum and concentrations offered by the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) program?
qa_list.answer: The MCDS Program offers a core curriculum and several concentrations; students entering the program enroll in core courses in their first semester and select further courses to satisfy at least one concentration. Students construct their own course of study, in consultation with their academic advisor, in order to satisfy broad guidelines.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Appendix A in this handbook?
qa_list.answer: Appendix A contains information about various resources and offices that graduate students are encouraged to consult during their tenure at Carnegie Mellon University, including The Word, the student handbook, the Office of Graduate and Postdoctoral Affairs, the Office of the Dean of Students, and others.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree?
qa_list.answer: The MCDS degree offers students with a Bachelor's degree the opportunity to improve their training with advanced study in Computer Science and Machine Learning.

qa_list.question: What is the structure of the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) program?
qa_list.answer: The MCDS Program typically consists of courses, seminars, and a final project. Most students will complete the program in three semesters; students coming from other disciplines and students focus on developing applied research skills in preparation for further graduate study or research-oriented employment may require an additional fourth semester.

qa_list.question: What is the role of academic advisors in the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) program?
qa_list.answer: Academic advisors play a crucial role in helping students construct their own course of study, in consultation with their advisor, to satisfy broad guidelines.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of concentrations in the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) program?
qa_list.answer: Concentrations allow students entering the program enroll in core courses in their first semester and select further courses to satisfy at least one concentration. Students construct their own course of study, in consultation with their academic advisor, in order to satisfy broad guidelines.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the Language Technologies Institute (LTI) in offering the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree?
qa_list.answer: The Language Technologies Institute (LTI), a department in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University, offers the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree.

qa_list.question: What are students required to do in their first semester of the MCDS program?
qa_list.answer: Students entering the program enroll in core courses.

qa_list.question: How many months is the typical duration of the MCDS program?
qa_list.answer: The MCDS program is typically a 16-month program consisting of courses, seminars, a required Capstone Project and a required summer internship or practical training.

qa_list.question: What are the broad guidelines that students follow when constructing their course of study?
qa_list.answer: Students construct their own course of study in consultation with their academic advisor to satisfy broad guidelines.

qa_list.question: Can a student tailor their coursework in a given concentration to follow a particular area of emphasis?
qa_list.answer: Yes, students can tailor their coursework in a given concentration to follow a particular area of emphasis.

qa_list.question: What is the typical outcome for MCDS graduates after completing the program?
qa_list.answer: While some MCDS graduates continue on to PhD programs in the LTI or other leading universities, most graduates go on to jobs in various industries.

qa_list.question: What are students required to do after completing their core courses?
qa_list.answer: After completing their core courses, students select further courses to satisfy at least one concentration.

qa_list.question: How many concentrations can a student choose from in the MCDS program?
qa_list.answer: The text does not specify how many concentrations are available for students to choose from.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Capstone Project required by the MCDS program?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the Capstone Project in the MCDS program is not specified in the given text.

qa_list.question: Is a summer internship or practical training mandatory for students enrolled in the MCDS program?
qa_list.answer: Yes, a required summer internship or practical training is part of the typical 16-month MCDS program.

qa_list.question: What is the Master's program in Computational Data Science at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Master’s Thesis is not required for this program. It consists entirely of coursework and a Capstone Project, which may lead to a publication.

qa_list.question: What kind of research activities are the Capstone projects in Computational Data Science structured as?
qa_list.answer: The Capstone projects in Computational Data Science are structured as research activities.

qa_list.question: Does Carnegie Mellon University have a Doctoral program in Computational Data Science?
qa_list.answer: No, there is no Doctoral program in Computational Data Science at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: How can performing well in the Master's program in Computational Data Science benefit a PhD application?
qa_list.answer: Performing well in the highly selective MCDS program will give a boost to a PhD application.

qa_list.question: Are MS graduates from Carnegie Mellon University given preferential treatment when applying for CMU's PhD programs?
qa_list.answer: MS graduates are welcome to apply, but they will not receive preferential treatment.

qa_list.question: What is the main document that informs graduate students of their program requirements and procedures in each department at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Each department issues a handbook to inform graduate students about their program requirements and procedures.

qa_list.question: What is the main purpose of the Master's degree in Computational Data Science according to the document?
qa_list.answer: The MCDS degree prepares students for deep disciplinary knowledge, problem-solving skills, leadership, communication, and interpersonal skills.

qa_list.question: What is Carnegie Mellon University's vision according to the document?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon University aims to have a transformative impact on society through continual innovation in education, research, creativity, and entrepreneurship.

qa_list.question: What is Carnegie Mellon University's mission according to the document?
qa_list.answer: The university's mission is to create a transformative educational experience for students focused on deep disciplinary knowledge; problem-solving skills, leadership, communication, and interpersonal skills; and personal health and well-being.

qa_list.question: What are the four key areas that can flourish with research, creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship?
qa_list.answer: The four key areas mentioned in the text where research, creativity, innovation, and entrepreneurship can flourish are not specified.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of engaging with partners outside the traditional borders of the university campus?
qa_list.answer: The purpose mentioned in the text for engaging with partners outside the traditional borders of the university campus is to impact society in a transformative way regionally, nationally and globally.

qa_list.answer: The people responsible for administering the MCDS degree according to the text are Jennifer M Lucas, Carolyn Penstein Rosé and Robert Frederking.

qa_list.answer: The Language Technologies Institute is primarily located on the 5th and 6th floors of the Gates Hillman Complex (GHC) on Carnegie Mellon’s Pittsburgh campus.

qa_list.question: What is the Carnegie Mellon University's statement on discrimination?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon University does not discriminate in admission, employment or administration of its programs or activities on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, handicap or disability, age, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, creed, ancestry, belief, veteran status or genetic information.

qa_list.question: Does the university publish an annual campus security and fire safety report?
qa_list.answer: Yes, Carnegie Mellon University does publish an annual campus security and fire safety report. This report includes information about the university's security policies, alcohol and drug policies, sexual assault policies, and statistics on crimes committed on campus.

qa_list.answer: Yes, the annual campus security and fire safety report is also available for viewing on the university's website at www.cmu.edu/police/annualreports.

qa_list.question: What information can be found in the Title IX webpage?
qa_list.answer: The Title IX webpage provides information about how Carnegie Mellon University applies Title IX, including its policies on admission and employment decisions. It also includes details about sexual misconduct grievance procedures and processes.

qa_list.question: How can students file a report or complaint of sex discrimination?
qa_list.answer: Students can file a report or complaint of sex discrimination by visiting the Title IX webpage at www.cmu.edu/title-ix.

qa_list.question: How does Carnegie Mellon University respond to reports of sexual harassment?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon University has a process in place for handling and responding to reports of sexual harassment. This information can be found on the Title IX webpage at www.cmu.edu/title-ix.

qa_list.question: What is the phone number for Carnegie Mellon Police Department?
qa_list.answer: The phone number for the Carnegie Mellowhile Mellon Police Department is 412-268-2323.

qa_list.question: What is the contact information for coordinator at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The contact information for the coordinator at Carnegie Mellon University is 412-268-7125 or tix@cmu.edu.

qa_list.question: What are the expectations of students at Carnegie Mellon in terms of personal, ethical and moral conduct?
qa_list.answer: Students at Carnegie Mellon are expected to meet the highest standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct possible. This includes personal integrity, a commitment to honesty without compromise, truthfulness without equivocation, and a willingness to prioritize the good of the community over self-interest.

qa_list.question: What is the location of the Main Office for The Language Technologies Institute at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Main Office for The Language Technologies Institute at Carnegie Mellon University is located in Gates Hillman Complex, specifically in room 5404.

qa_list.question: What are the standards of conduct expected from students at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Students at Carnegie Mellon are expected to uphold high standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct. They must commit to meeting obligations once undertaken, keep their commitments, respect the creativity and knowledge of others, and not compromise on honesty.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of The Carnegie Mellon Code?
qa_list.answer: The Carnegie Mellon Code outlines the standards of conduct expected from students at Carnegie Mellon University. It emphasizes personal integrity, honesty without compromise, truthfulness without equivocation, and a commitment to upholding community standards.

qa_list.question: Where can students find The Carnegie Mellon Code?
qa_list.answer: Students can find The Carnegie Mellon Code online at https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/. They can also contact the coordinator for more information.

qa_list.question: What is the role of faculty, staff and students in maintaining The Carnegie Mellon Code?
qa_list.answer: The commitment of faculty, staff, and students to uphold The Carnegie Mellon Code contributes to the high respect in which the university degree is held. Students who cannot meet these standards should voluntarily withdraw from the university.

qa_list.question: What are the consequences for students who fail to meet the expectations of conduct at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Students who fail to meet the expectations of personal, ethical and moral conduct may face serious consequences. They should voluntarily withdraw from the university.

qa_list.question: What is required for MS students to access university resources?
qa_list.answer: MS students are expected to provide their own laptop computers that can be used to access university resources and complete course assignments.

qa_list.question: Where can full-time MS students in the LTI’s program find a shared working space on campus?
qa_list.answer: Full-time MS students in the LTI’s programs have access to a shared working space to create a sense of community and provide space for working when on campus.

qa_list.question: What is required for MS students to use department printers?
qa_list.answer: MS students will be given a CS user id, which is required to use the LTI computer cluster, department printers, and other SCS services.

qa_list.question: Where can MS students get help with university resources?
qa_list.answer: The School of Computer Science has a Help Center located at 4203 GHC. They can be contacted at help@cs.cmu.edu, extension 8-4231 from a campus phone, or 412-268-4231 from an outside line.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of providing CS user id to MS students?
qa_list.answer: A CS user id is provided to MS students for accessing university resources, completing course assignments and directed study projects, and/or the capstone project.

qa_list.question: Where can full-time MS students in the LTI’s program find a shared working space on campus?
qa_list.answer: Full-time MS students in the LTI’s programs have access to a shared working space to create a sense of community and provide space for working when on campus.

qa_list.question: What is required for MS students to use department printers?
qa_list.answer: MS students will be given a CS user id, which is required to use the LTI computer cluster, department printers, and other SCS services.

qa_list.question: Where can MS students get help with university resources?
qa_list.answer: The School of Computer Science has a Help Center located at 4203 GHC. They can be contacted at help@cs.cmu.edu, extension 8-4231 from a campus phone, or 412-268-4231 from an outside line.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of providing CS user id to MS students?
qa_list.answer: A CS user id is provided to MS students for accessing university resources, completing course assignments and directed study projects, and/or the capstone project.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of giving MS students access to LTI's computer cluster?
qa_list.answer: MS students are given access to the LTI’s computer cluster for course assignments, directed study projects, and/or the capstone project. The LTI cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets and/or lengthy computations.

qa_list.question: What is described in section 3 of MCDS Degree Completion and Certification?
qa_list.answer: Section 3 describes the various rules and regulations that determine the attainment of a MCDS degree by the student.

qa_list.question: What is the standard length of time for graduate students to complete their program of study as outlined in the relevant Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The standard program lengths for graduate students vary significantly – ranging from two semesters for some full-time master’s programs to several or more years for doctoral programs.

qa_list.question: What happens upon completion of the graduate program degree requirements?
qa_list.answer: Upon completion of the graduate program degree requirements, the degree will be certified by the student’s academic program in the semester in which the student completes the requirements.

qa_list.question: What is Early Completion for graduate students?
qa_list.answer: Early completion refers to graduate students who consider the completion of all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study. These students may consult with their degree-granting department.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Early Completion?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of early completion is to allow graduate students who have completed all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study to consult with their degree-granting department.

qa_list.question: What are the benefits of Early Completion?
qa_list.answer: The benefits of early completion include being able to complete your graduate studies in less than the standard length of time, which can save you both time and money. It also allows students who have completed their degree requirements early to consult with their degree-granting department.

qa_list.question: What is the statute of limitations for Carnegie Mellon graduate students?
qa_list.answer: The statute of limitations refers to the maximum period after an event within which a lawsuit must be filed. For Carnegie Mellon graduate students, it means that they are expected to complete their degree requirements within the standard length of time for their program of study as outlined in the relevant Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the role of Early Completion in Carnegie Mellon graduate students?
qa_list.answer: Early completion plays a significant role in allowing Carnegie Mellon graduate students who have completed all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study to consult with their degree-granting department.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of determining if early degree certification is allowed?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of determining if early degree certification is allowed is to ensure that students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are able to do so under specific circumstances.

qa_list.question: What might cause a Master's student to require longer-than-standard completion?
qa_list.answer: A Master's student may require longer-than-standard completion due to academic interruptions, full-time study or progress towards the degree being interrupted by serious medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.

qa_list.question: What is expected of Master’s students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements?
qa_list.answer: Master's students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program and will be certified at the end.

qa_list.question: What is extended or longer-than-standard completion?
qa_list.answer: Extended or longer-than-standard completion refers to a situation where students take more time than usual to complete their degree requirements due to academic interruptions, medical issues, or other unforeseen circumstances.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the granting program or department in determining if early degree certification is allowed?
qa_list.answer: The granting program or department plays a crucial role in determining whether students can receive their degrees earlier than usual, based on specific circumstances such as academic interruptions, medical issues, or other unforeseen situations.

qa_list.question: What happens to Master's students who require longer-than-standard completion?
qa_list.answer: Master's students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements will be certified at the end, after they have remained in close contact with their graduate program.

qa_list.question: What are some reasons why a Master's student might need extended or longer-than-standard completion?
qa_list.answer: Master's students may require extended or longer-than-standard completion due to academic interruptions, full-time study being interrupted by serious medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of determining if early degree certification is allowed under what circumstances?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of determining if early degree certification is allowed under specific circumstances is to ensure that students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are able to do so in a fair and flexible manner.

qa_list.question: What does it mean when Master's students are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program?
qa_list.answer: When Master's students are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program, they must maintain regular communication and engagement with the academic staff and faculty members responsible for overseeing their degree progress.

1 Welcome Welcome to the Language Technologies Institute, Master of
Computational Data Science Program. While this handbook is specific to
your academic experience in the department, there are several other
resources and offices graduate students are encouraged to consult during
their tenure at Carnegie Mellon University. Information about The Word,
the student handbook, the Office of Graduate and Postdoctoral Affairs, the
Office of the Dean of Students, and others are included in Appendix A of
this handbook.
1.1 The MCDS Degree The MCDS Degree The Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS)
degree is a professional Master of Science degree offered by the Language
Technologies Institute (LTI), a department in the School of Computer
Science at Carnegie Mellon University. The MCDS degree offers students
with a Bachelor's degree the opportunity to improve their training with
advanced study in Computer Science and Machine Learning. We cater to
students with basic analytic skills and a strong aptitude for mathematics,
programming, and logical reasoning. An undergraduate degree in
Computer Science is not required. Most students will complete the
program in three semesters; students coming from other disciplines and
students focus on developing applied research skills in preparation for
further graduate study or research-oriented employment may require an
additional fourth semester.
The MCDS Program offers a core curriculum and several concentrations;
students entering the program enroll in core courses in their first
semester and select further courses to satisfy at least one concentration
(see Section 3.3.6). Students construct their own course of study, in
consultation with their academic advisor, in order to satisfy broad
guidelines. Thus, a student may tailor their coursework in a given
concentration to follow a particular area of emphasis. The MCDS program
is typically a 16-month program consisting of courses, seminars, a
required Capstone Project and a required summer internship or practical
training. While some MCDS graduates continue on to PhD programs in the
LTI or other leading universities, most graduates go on to jobs in
6


corporate research and development laboratories.
The program consists entirely of coursework and a Capstone Project, and
no Master’s Thesis is required. All Capstone projects are structured as
research activities and may lead to a publication. There is no Doctoral
program in Computational Data Science. Because of the highly selective
nature of the MCDS program and quality of the MCDS curriculum,
performing well in the program will give a boost to a PhD application. MS
graduates are welcome to apply to CMU PhD programs but will not receive
preferential treatment.
There are significant differences between CMU's different departments
and degree programs in philosophical approach, procedures, policies and
regulations. Each department issues a handbook that informs graduate
students of their program requirements and procedures and ensures that
students have written access to the standard information outlined below.
This handbook describes the policies, procedures, and requirements for
the Master of Computational Data Science (MCDS) degree.
All policies not explicitly described in this document conform to School of
Computer Science (SCS) policies and university policies described in The
Word, Carnegie Mellon University Student Handbook and at the
University Policies website.
1.2 Vision Carnegie Mellon University will have a transformative impact on society
through continual innovation in education, research, creativity, and
entrepreneurship.
1.3 Mission To create a transformative educational experience for students focused on
deep disciplinary knowledge; problem solving; leadership,
communication, and interpersonal skills; and personal health and well-
being.
To cultivate a transformative university community committed to (a)
attracting and retaining diverse, world-class talent; (b) creating a
collaborative environment open to the free exchange of ideas, where
7


research, creativity, innovation, and entrepreneurship can flourish; and
(c) ensuring individuals can achieve their full potential.
To impact society in a transformative way — regionally, nationally, and
globally — by engaging with partners outside the traditional borders of the
university campus.
1.4 MCDS Contact Information The people responsible for administering the MCDS degree are:
Jennifer M Lucas Academic Program Manager Master of Computational Data Science Language Technologies Institute School of Computer Science Carnegie Mellon University Gates-Hillman Center 6415 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pgh, PA 15213 Phone: (412) 268-9870 Fax: (412) 268-7287
Carolyn Penstein Rosé, Director Master of Computational Data Science Language Technologies Institute School of Computer Science Carnegie Mellon University Gates-Hillman Center 5419 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pgh, PA 15213 Phone: (412) 268-4525 Fax: (412) 268-7287
Robert Frederking Graduate Program Chair Language Technologies Institute School of Computer Science Carnegie Mellon University Gates-Hillman Center 6515 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pgh, PA 15213 Phone: (412) 268-6656
Mona Diab, LTI Director Language Technologies Institute School of Computer Science Carnegie Mellon University Gates-Hillman Center 5723 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pgh, PA 15213 Phone: (412) 268-3669
The Language Technologies Institute is located primarily on the 5 th and 6th floors of the Gates Hillman Complex (GHC) on Carnegie Mellon’s Pittsburgh campus:
Language Technologies Institute Carnegie Mellon University 5000 Forbes Avenue Gates Hillman Complex 5402, LTI Pittsburgh, PA 15241-3891
412-268-6591 (phone) 412-268-6298 (fax) http://www.lti.cs.cmu.edu/
8


1.5 University Policies and Expectations Each member of the Carnegie Mellon community must be familiar with university policies and guidelines. In addition to this departmental graduate student handbook, the following resources are available to assist you in understanding community expectations:
The Word/Student Handbook: Academic Integrity Website: University Policies Website: Office of Graduate and Post-Doc Affairs:
http://www.cmu.edu/student- affairs/theword/index.html https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student- life/academic-integrity.html http://www.cmu.edu/policies/
http://www.cmu.edu/graduate/policies/index.html
Please see Appendix A for additional information about university resources.
1.6 Carnegie Mellon University Statement of Assurance Carnegie Mellon University does not discriminate in admission, employment or administration of its programs or activities on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, handicap or disability, age, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, creed, ancestry, belief, veteran status or genetic information. Furthermore, Carnegie Mellon University does not discriminate and is required not to discriminate in violation of federal, state or local laws or executive orders.
Inquiries concerning the application of and compliance with this statement should be directed to the university ombudsman, Carnegie Mellon University, 5000 Forbes Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, telephone 412-268-1018. Obtain general information about Carnegie Mellon University by calling 412-268-2000.
Carnegie Mellon University publishes an annual campus security and fire safety report. describing the university's security, alcohol and drug, sexual assault and fire safety policies, and containing statistics about the number and type of crimes committed on the campus, and the number and cause of fires in campus residence facilities during the preceding three years. You can obtain a copy by contacting the Carnegie Mellon Police Department at 412-268-2323. The annual security and fire safety report also is available online at www.cmu.edu/police/annualreports.
Information regarding the application of Title IX, including to admission and employment decisions, the sexual misconduct grievance procedures and process, including how to file a report or a complaint of sex discrimination, how to file a report of sexual harassment, and how the university responds to such reports is available at www.cmu.edu/title-ix. The Title IX
9


coordinator may be reached at 412-268-7125 or tix@cmu.edu.
1.7 The Carnegie Mellon Code
Students at Carnegie Mellon, because they are members of an academic community dedicated to the achievement of excellence, are expected to meet the highest standards of personal, ethical and moral conduct possible.
These standards require personal integrity, a commitment to honesty without compromise, as well as truth without equivocation and a willingness to place the good of the community above the good of the self. Obligations once undertaken must be met, commitments kept.
As members of the Carnegie Mellon community, individuals are expected to uphold the standards of the community in addition to holding others accountable for said standards. It is rare that the life of a student in an academic community can be so private that it will not affect the community as a whole or that the above standards do not apply.
The discovery, advancement and communication of knowledge are not possible without a commitment to these standards. Creativity cannot exist without acknowledgment of the creativity of others. New knowledge cannot be developed without credit for prior knowledge. Without the ability to trust that these principles will be observed, an academic community cannot exist.
The commitment of its faculty, staff and students to these standards contributes to the high respect in which the Carnegie Mellon degree is held. Students must not destroy that respect by their failure to meet these standards. Students who cannot meet them should voluntarily withdraw from the university.
The Carnegie Mellon Code can also be found on-line at: https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/.
2 The Language Technologies Institute
2.1 Main Office The Gates Hillman Complex: Mailboxes, printers, copiers, and other departmental resources are in GHC 5404.
10


2.2 Photocopies and Printers The use of a printer/copier requires a CS user id (see the ‘Computers’ section). The School of Computer Science provides several black-and-white and color printers for use by students. SCS Computing Facilities maintains a list of printers: http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~help/printing/.
2.3 Office Space for MS Students Full-time students in the LTI’s MS degree programs on the Pittsburgh campus have access to a shared working space to create a sense of community and provide space for working when on campus.
2.4 Computers for MS Students Students are expected to provide their own laptop computers that can be used to access university resources and complete course assignments. Laptops running Windows, MacOS, and Linux software are all acceptable.
MS students will be given a CS user id. A CS user id is required to use the LTI computer cluster, department printers, and other SCS services. The School of Computer Science has a Help Center located at 4203 GHC. They can be contacted at help@cs.cmu.edu, extension 8-4231 from a campus phone, or 412-268-4231 from an outside line.
MS students will be given access to the LTI’s computer cluster on an as-needed basis, to be used for course assignments, directed study projects, and/or the capstone project. The LTI cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets and/or lengthy computation.
3 MCDS Degree Completion and Certification This section describes the various rules and regulations that determine the attainment of a MCDS degree by the student.
3.1 CMU Degree Completion and Statute of Limitations Carnegie Mellon graduate students are expected to complete their degree requirements within the standard length of time for their program of study as outlined in the relevant Graduate Student Handbook. Standard program lengths for graduate students vary significantly – ranging from two semesters for some full-time master’s programs to several or more years for doctoral programs. Upon completion of the graduate program degree requirements, the degree will be certified by the student’s academic program in the semester in which the student completes the requirements.
Early Completion
Graduate students who consider the completion of all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study may consult with their degree-
11


granting program or department to determine if early degree certification is allowed and under what circumstances.
Extended or Longer-than-Standard Completion
Longer-than-standard degree completion may occur due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances. Master’s students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program and will be certified at the end
